text: Hello! I am looking for an external copy writer - we are a database and data orchestration company called TerminusDB. We're expanding and want to get regular copy out on the web (site and SaaS product), blogs and other stuff. A lot of the base material is deeply technical, so really looking for somebody who is comfortable taking complex technical ideas and translating them into slightly more digestible copy. We are targeting developers and blogs appearing high on Hacker News and the likes is big for us. Any recommendations or suggestions very welcome!

text: Hello! Anyone have a great resource on how to write scripts for tech product how-to videos? I’ve never done video scripts before!

elements.text: Hello! Anyone have a great resource on how to write scripts for tech product how-to videos? I’ve never done video scripts before!

text:
Hey! This is how I do it, others may take a different approach:

You can usually learn a great deal from the product brief and talking to the video director. How long will the video be? What are the main "beats" the product team wants you to hit with the content? How much time will need to be devoted to the company's branding segment (is this standard across all videos, so you don't have to write it? or are you responsible for this too?)? How much time will need to be devoted for a CTA screen at the end? How many cameras will be used during filming (usually two or three—front, above, close up freehand)? Will some close up and overhead work be filmed separately and then patched in during editing (if so, you may need to create multiple scripts)? And then, once you know all this information, it becomes mostly a math problem. A 5min video with a 15 second brand intro and 15 second CTA screen at the end means you'd have 4:45 to cover X number of features. Break it down, write it up, separate the script (if necessary), and give it to the product team for edits. I usually aim for 150-160 words per minute—if your speaker is going faster than 160, it's usually too fast for a video audience.

The problem with video scripts is that people read faster than they speak when they're in a conversation. (You can read 200+ words a minute, but speaking that quickly would make someone sound very, very nervous.) So it is likely that your product team will read your script and say that it's too short, and that your acting talent will read faster from the prompter cards than they would if speaking off the cuff. Be prepared to push back a bit if you're told it's too short. You want your script to sound like real people talking about a product, not a race to cram stuff into the script.

text: Do you have a sales team in your company? Seems a little backward, but that's always been my first stop in that situation. If they're pitching the product/service all day long, they've likely found a good way to summarize what it is concisely and for a broad swath of folks.

text: I actually find it flows like a "basic how-to" blog post than anything else. I've used graphical elements like H2 headers for each feature. Then the first spoken sentence of each feature is always really direct about what the feature is and why it has value to a user ("The XYZ feature was created to help users better ABC.") From there it goes into step-by-step directions of how to utilize that feature. And then the last sentence of the feature section might be real-world examples or some "insider secret" or something along those lines to really hit home the idea of how the user will engage with the feature. Reviewing the information at the end of the video is also good, too, for reiterating what was covered. Honestly, if you have any friends who are school teachers, they would be great to ask about explanatory methods.

text: <@U01MGBGFJ9K> you're missing an SEO advantage here by posting the blogs on medium. Instead, publish them on your site. Then, submit those blogs on medium as stories. It is called canonicalization and Google loves it

text: As far as voice is concerned, the product videos on YouTube with some of the best ratings are those that don't look too slick. If the presenter comes off as a real user more than a product salesperson, that seems to work wonderfully. I'm not responsible for the Peak Design videos, but they're one example of the "real user" feel that I think resonates with a lot of people. Authenticity goes a long way.

text: :wave: <@U019NVAFFJQ>.  I own a business that creates/fulfills content programs for dev tools companies, and a company in the DataOps space would definitely be in our wheelhouse.  But even if you're looking to directly contract a freelance software engineer or data engineer author rather than an agency-style partner, I'm happy to offer thoughts on where to look, and can help you match-make.  We have a mailing list of something like 800 engineers looking for content side hustles, and we curate opportunities through it both for us, and for anyone looking to work directly with them.  Please feel free to send me a DM, if you'd like.  (I'll probably be out of pocket the rest of the day, so I might not respond until tomorrow)

I ask because I'm feeling the pinch of having a one-person operation (me) for my weekly show, and I'd like to build the case for a larger team.

text: Hey Drew - I haven't done them before, but in exploring options I came across these folks (<https://www.thepodcasthost.com/>) and figured I'd drop you the link to explore in case you found it helpful. Seems they can help folks start, but also optimize their podcasts. They also link to folks on Fiverr, etc who can help with editing, art, writing notes, etc (<https://www.thepodcasthost.com/podcast-production-directory/>) -- and i believe they can help if you have bigger budgets, etc

text:
Does anyone else use a different approach to "buyer personas"?

For some reason I feel that creating the typical one-pager persona for content isn't the best way to describe a target market. I'm curious to hear how other people do this.

elements.text:
Does anyone else use a different approach to "buyer personas"?

For some reason I feel that creating the typical one-pager persona for content isn't the best way to describe a target market. I'm curious to hear how other people do this.

text: I’d prefer a psychographic approach to personas, for example

elements.text: I’d prefer a psychographic approach to personas, for example

text:
I ~hate~ dislike the standard “Tara, 27, 2dogs 1 cat, commutes” user persona

I find “Tara, leads a team of 7, is strapped for time, needs to solve problem A and B but has no budget” more appealing

More info about this approach here if you’re interested → <https://www.hotjar.com/blog/psychographics-in-marketing/>

:slightly_smiling_face:

text: Yeah, I find the corny vignettes cringey and fairly useless from a creative standpoint. What has been useful for me are direct quotes from actual customers that describe their problems. With 4-7 statements in front of me, I can find patterns and common words, etc.

text:
Jobs To Be Done, 1000%.  Just tends to be way more actionable than focusing on demographics.

This book from Intercom is product-focused but easy to convert their concepts into content observations <https://www.intercom.com/resources/books/intercom-jobs-to-be-done>

attachments.title: Intercom Resources
attachments.text: Check out Intercom's resources on customer support, lead generation, customer engagement, and everything in between. No fluff or sales pitches. Just quality information and insights.

text:
The agency where I work has two psychographic personas. The first is "our ideal client" and the second is akin to "meh, we don't hate this client." We refer to the "ideal client" occasionally, but the persona is such an ingrained part of our messaging, we use it more as a training tool for new staff. However, we use our "meh, we don't hate this client" all the time. We use it when we are looking for reasons to NOT take on a client. If a potential client doesn't even meet the "meh, we don't hate this client" standards, we pass them along to another agency. It's an on-going team joke to go into the file and add comments or qualities to the "meh" persona. The additions are always funny, and some of the things I have to remove, but a few stay in the persona because they're so perfect. I've also had a blast changing up the "people" by using the site <https://thispersondoesnotexist.com/> For awhile, "Meh" was Joe the weather guy from American Ninja Warrior. This probably isn't answering your question ...

I guess my intent is that personas are only valuable if you use them. If they're not something your team is going to get value from, find a method that will hold utility.

text: *Backlink opportunity:* Seeking managers who can share insights/experience related to encouraging team members to self-manage. Here's a survey if you're interested (need responses by end of day Tuesday, February 16th): <https://forms.gle/qxMufvPGSy72kA2c7>

attachments.title: Survey: Encouraging Self-Management in the Workplace
attachments.text: We're working on an article for <http://Uptickapp.com|Uptickapp.com> about how using aspects of self-management can be beneficial to companies and teams. You do NOT have to embrace self-management in all areas of your business to respond to this survey. We're interested in any insights related to the benefits of using self-management principles at work, including encouraging your team to work autonomously. All quotes used in the article will be attributed with a backlink to your site. Thank you for sharing your insights!
attachments.fallback: Google Docs: Survey: Encouraging Self-Management in the Workplace

text: Hey all -- I'm looking for some advice. I'm hiring for a very writing-intensive job, and I have a candidate that everyone really likes, but she does not have writing samples that really meet what we're looking for. Has anyone successfully given a writing test that they felt was a good way to assess a candidate? (we're happy to pay for the work if we don't hire this candidate)

elements.text: Hey all -- I'm looking for some advice. I'm hiring for a very writing-intensive job, and I have a candidate that everyone really likes, but she does not have writing samples that really meet what we're looking for. Has anyone successfully given a writing test that they felt was a good way to assess a candidate? (we're happy to pay for the work if we don't hire this candidate)

text: yep, give them a test that's basically exactly the same thing they'll be doing in the role. i've moved to doing brief freelance contracts (3-4 articles) because it's very hard to make an assessment from 1 article. i also make sure to include 1 round of revisions, to gauge how they follow feedback/edits.
